sn12.27:1.3.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.27:1.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.27:2.1.eng: And what is old age and death?

sn12.27:2.2.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jarā jīraṇatā khaṇḍiccaṃ pāliccaṃ valittacatā āyuno saṃhāni indriyānaṃ paripāko—
sn12.27:2.2.eng: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

sn12.27:2.4.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṃ maccu maraṇaṃ kālakiriyā khandhānaṃ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo;
sn12.27:2.4.eng: The passing away, passing on, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, and laying to rest of the corpse of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

sn12.27:2.6.eng: Such is old age, and such is death.

sn12.27:2.7.eng: This is called old age and death.

sn12.27:2.8.eng: Rebirth is the origin of old age and death.

sn12.27:2.9.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death cease.

sn12.27:2.10.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminī paṭipadā.
sn12.27:2.10.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death is simply this noble eightfold path,
sn12.27:2.10.comm: Normally the path leads to the cessation of “suffering”. This shows another way of integrating dependent origination with the path.

sn12.27:2.11.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
sn12.27:2.11.eng: that is: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn12.27:3.1.comm: The remaining items are presumably to be expanded per SN 12.2.

sn12.27:3.7.eng: And what are the six sense fields? …

sn12.27:3.8.eng: And what are name and form? …

sn12.27:4.2.eng: There are three kinds of choices.

sn12.27:4.3.eng: Choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn12.27:4.5.eng: Ignorance is the origin of choices.

sn12.27:4.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅkhāranirodhagāminī paṭipadā.
sn12.27:4.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of choices is simply this noble eightfold path,

sn12.27:4.8.eng: that is: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn12.27:5.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ paccayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayasamudayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ paccayanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti.
sn12.27:5.1.eng: When a noble disciple thus understands dependency, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
sn12.27:5.1.comm: One who knows the path and dependent origination is a stream-enterer, for which the next phrase supplies a series of synonyms.

sn12.27:5.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako diṭṭhisampanno itipi, dassanasampanno itipi, āgato imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, passati imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, sekkhena ñāṇena samannāgato itipi, sekkhāya vijjāya samannāgato itipi, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno itipi, ariyo nibbedhikapañño itipi, amatadvāraṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati itipī”ti.
sn12.27:5.2.eng: that noble disciple is called: ‘one accomplished in view’, ‘one accomplished in vision’, ‘one who has come to the true teaching’, ‘one who sees this true teaching’, ‘one endowed with a trainee’s knowledge’, ‘one who has entered the stream of the teaching’, ‘a noble one with penetrative wisdom’, and also ‘one who stands pressing against the door to freedom from death’.”
sn12.27:5.2.comm: The idiom āhacca tiṭṭhati is used for the river “pressing into” the ocean (MN 73:14.1), or the tongue “pressed against” the roof of the mouth (MN 100:17.2).

sn12.28:1.3.pli: idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jarāmaraṇaṃ pajānāti, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ pajānāti, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ pajānāti, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, jātiṃ pajānāti …pe…
sn12.28:1.3.eng: “A mendicant understands old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. They understand rebirth …

sn12.28:1.12.pli: saṅkhāre pajānāti, saṅkhārasamudayaṃ pajānāti, saṅkhāranirodhaṃ pajānāti, saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti.
sn12.28:1.12.eng: They understand choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation.

sn12.28:2.1.eng: And what is old age and death?

sn12.28:2.2.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jarā jīraṇatā khaṇḍiccaṃ pāliccaṃ valittacatā āyuno saṃhāni indriyānaṃ paripāko—
sn12.28:2.2.eng: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

sn12.28:2.4.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṃ maccu maraṇaṃ kālakiriyā khandhānaṃ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo;
sn12.28:2.4.eng: The passing away, passing on, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, and laying to rest of the corpse of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

sn12.28:2.6.eng: Such is old age, and such is death.

sn12.28:2.7.eng: This is called old age and death.

sn12.28:2.8.eng: Rebirth is the origin of old age and death.

sn12.28:2.9.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death cease.

sn12.28:2.10.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminī paṭipadā.
sn12.28:2.10.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death is simply this noble eightfold path,

sn12.28:2.11.eng: that is: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn12.28:4.2.eng: There are three kinds of choices.

sn12.28:4.3.eng: Choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn12.28:4.5.eng: Ignorance is the origin of choices.

sn12.28:4.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅkhāranirodhagāminī paṭipadā.
sn12.28:4.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of choices is simply this noble eightfold path,

sn12.28:4.8.eng: that is: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn12.28:5.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jātiṃ pajānāti …pe…
sn12.28:5.1.eng: A mendicant understands old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. They understand rebirth …

sn12.28:5.13.eng: and the practice that leads to their cessation.

sn12.28:5.14.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu diṭṭhisampanno itipi, dassanasampanno itipi, āgato imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, passati imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, sekkhena ñāṇena samannāgato itipi, sekkhāya vijjāya samannāgato itipi, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno itipi, ariyo nibbedhikapañño itipi, amatadvāraṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati itipī”ti.
sn12.28:5.14.eng: This mendicant is called: ‘one accomplished in view’, ‘one accomplished in vision’, ‘one who has come to the true teaching’, ‘one who sees this true teaching’, ‘one endowed with a trainee’s knowledge’, ‘one who has entered the stream of the teaching’, ‘a noble one with penetrative wisdom’, and also ‘one who stands pressing against the door to freedom from death’.”

sn12.29:1.3.pli: ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā jarāmaraṇaṃ na parijānanti, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ na parijānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ na parijānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na parijānanti, jātiṃ na parijānanti …pe…
sn12.29:1.3.eng: “There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t completely understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. They don’t completely understand rebirth …

sn12.29:1.12.comm: The sequence does not go back to ignorance because this is assumed in the premise, those who do not understand.

sn12.29:1.15.eng: and the practice that leads to their cessation.

sn12.29:1.16.pli: Na mete, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā. Na ca panete āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn12.29:1.16.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn12.29:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā jarāmaraṇaṃ parijānanti, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ parijānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ parijānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ parijānanti, jātiṃ parijānanti …pe…
sn12.29:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who completely understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. They completely understand rebirth …

sn12.29:2.10.pli: saṅkhāre parijānanti, saṅkhārasamudayaṃ parijānanti, saṅkhāranirodhaṃ parijānanti, saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ parijānanti.
sn12.29:2.10.eng: They completely understand choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation.

sn12.29:2.11.pli: Te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā. Te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn12.29:2.11.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn12.3:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the wrong practice and the right practice.
sn12.3:1.2.comm: This discourse, located so prominently in the Saṁyutta, heads off the misconception that dependent origination is purely a theoretical or philosophical doctrine. Obviously it has a philosophical dimension, but it is aligned with the path of practice which also proceeds via cessation. The next Sutta shows how the sequence unfolded as a contemplative reflection.

sn12.3:1.3.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn12.3:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn12.3:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn12.3:2.2.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

sn12.3:2.3.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.3:2.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.3:2.5.eng: This is called the wrong practice.

sn12.3:3.2.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

sn12.3:3.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.3:3.5.eng: This is called the right practice.”

sn12.30:1.3.pli: ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā jarāmaraṇaṃ nappajānanti, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti te vata jarāmaraṇaṃ samatikkamma ṭhassantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn12.30:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. It’s impossible that they will abide having transcended old age and death.
sn12.30:1.3.comm: “They will abide having transcended” is a unique phrase, reminiscent of language more commonly associated with eternalism (DN 1:2.9.3). Here refers to the perfected one, who abides in this world for the remainder of their lifespan, but has transcended rebirth.

sn12.30:1.13.pli: saṅkhāre nappajānanti, saṅkhārasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, saṅkhāranirodhaṃ nappajānanti, saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti te vata saṅkhāre samatikkamma ṭhassantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn12.30:1.13.eng: They don’t understand choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. It’s impossible that they will abide having transcended choices.

sn12.30:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā jarāmaraṇaṃ pajānanti, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ pajānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ pajānanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti te vata jarāmaraṇaṃ samatikkamma ṭhassantīti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
sn12.30:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. It’s possible that they will abide having transcended old age and death.

sn12.30:2.11.pli: saṅkhāre pajānanti, saṅkhārasamudayaṃ pajānanti, saṅkhāranirodhaṃ pajānanti, saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti.
sn12.30:2.11.eng: They understand choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation.

sn12.30:2.12.pli: Te vata saṅkhāre samatikkamma ṭhassantīti ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī”ti.
sn12.30:2.12.eng: It’s possible that they will abide having transcended choices.”

sn12.31:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī.

sn12.31:1.2.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āmantesi:
sn12.31:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Sāriputta,

sn12.31:1.3.eng: “Sāriputta, this was said in ‘The Way to the Far Shore’, in ‘The Questions of Ajita’:
sn12.31:1.3.comm: Ajita was one of a group of contemplative brahmins from a school that identified the cosmic divinity with the state of purified formless consciousness experienced in deep meditation. Their story is recounted in “The Way to the Far Shore”, where Ajita was the first to question the Buddha (Snp 5.2). The title is given in the text itself (Snp 5.18:8.4, Snp 5.19:1.1), and it is cited also in AN 3.32, AN 3.33, AN 4.41, AN 7.53, and AN 6.61.

sn12.31:2.1.eng: ‘There are those who have appraised the teaching,

sn12.31:2.2.eng: and many kinds of trainees here.

sn12.31:2.3.eng: Now you, being alert, are asked

sn12.31:2.4.eng: to tell me their behavior, good fellow.’

sn12.31:3.1.pli: Imassa nu kho, sāriputta, saṅkhittena bhāsitassa kathaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
sn12.31:3.1.eng: How should we see the detailed meaning of this brief statement?”
sn12.31:3.1.comm: In reply to Ajita, the Buddha already answered the question: a mendicant without greed, skillful, would wander mindful. Here he asks for a detailed analysis, presumably as a teaching method: the dialogue was probably in front of an assembly.

sn12.31:3.2.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto tuṇhī ahosi.
sn12.31:3.2.eng: When he said this, Sāriputta kept silent.
sn12.31:3.2.comm: Sāriputta hesitates, according to the commentary, because he is unsure of the mode of analysis that the Buddha wants him to pursue. This is typical of Sāriputta’s circumspection; he himself explains a similar hesitation in the next Sutta (SN 12.32:16.2).

sn12.31:4.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āmantesi …pe…

sn12.31:4.2.pli: dutiyampi kho āyasmā sāriputto tuṇhī ahosi.

sn12.31:4.3.pli: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āmantesi:

sn12.31:6.1.pli: Imassa nu kho, sāriputta, saṅkhittena bhāsitassa kathaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?

sn12.31:6.2.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā sāriputto tuṇhī ahosi.

sn12.31:7.1.eng: “Sāriputta, do you see that this has come to be?”
sn12.31:7.1.comm: See MN 38:9.1, where “this has come to be” refers to dependently originated consciousness. There, the Buddha is refuting Sāti, who believed consciousness is “the one who speaks, the one who knows, who experiences the results of good and bad deeds in all the different realms.” This is the Upaniṣadic view, which was apparently shared by both Ajita and Sāti, and against which the Buddha posited dependent origination.

sn12.31:7.2.eng: “Sir, one truly sees with right wisdom that this has come to be.

sn12.31:7.3.pli: Bhūtamidanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā bhūtassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn12.31:7.3.eng: Seeing this, one is practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding what has come to be.

sn12.31:7.4.eng: One truly sees with right wisdom that it originated with that as fuel.
sn12.31:7.4.comm: “Originated with that as fuel” is also at MN 38:9.3, cementing the connection between these two texts.

sn12.31:7.5.pli: Tadāhārasambhavanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā āhārasambhavassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn12.31:7.5.eng: Seeing this, one is practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the fuel for its origination.

sn12.31:7.6.pli: Tadāhāranirodhā yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn12.31:7.6.eng: One truly sees with right wisdom that when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease.

sn12.31:7.7.pli: Tadāhāranirodhā yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā nirodhadhammassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn12.31:7.7.eng: Seeing this, one is practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding what is liable to cease.

sn12.31:7.8.eng: In this way one is a trainee.
sn12.31:7.8.comm: Note that Sāriputta does not answer Ajita’s question on practice; rather, he analyzes the terms. This illustrates how analytical commentary developed from practical advice.

sn12.31:8.1.eng: And what, sir, is one who has appraised the teaching?

sn12.31:8.2.eng: Sir, one truly sees with right wisdom that this has come to be.

sn12.31:8.3.pli: Bhūtamidanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā bhūtassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto hoti.
sn12.31:8.3.eng: Seeing this, one is freed by not grasping through disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding what has come to be.
sn12.31:8.3.comm: The stream-enterer sees the truth, the arahant is fully freed.

sn12.31:8.4.eng: One truly sees with right wisdom that it originated with that as fuel.

sn12.31:8.5.pli: Tadāhārasambhavanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā āhārasambhavassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto hoti.
sn12.31:8.5.eng: Seeing this, one is freed by not grasping through disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the fuel for its origination.

sn12.31:8.6.pli: Tadāhāranirodhā yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn12.31:8.6.eng: One truly sees with right wisdom that when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease.

sn12.31:8.7.pli: Tadāhāranirodhā yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā nirodhadhammassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto hoti.
sn12.31:8.7.eng: Seeing this, one is freed by not grasping through disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding what is liable to cease.

sn12.31:8.8.eng: In this way one has appraised the teaching.

sn12.31:8.9.pli: Iti kho, bhante, yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ pārāyane ajitapañhe:
sn12.31:8.9.eng: Sir, regarding what was said in ‘The Way to the Far Shore’, in ‘The Questions of Ajita’:

sn12.31:9.1.eng: ‘There are those who have appraised the teaching,

sn12.31:9.2.eng: and many kinds of trainees here.

sn12.31:9.3.eng: Now you, being alert, are asked

sn12.31:9.4.eng: to tell me their behavior, good fellow.’

sn12.31:10.1.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn12.31:10.1.eng: This is how I understand the detailed meaning of what was said in brief.”

sn12.31:11.1.pli: “Sādhu sādhu, sāriputta, bhūtamidanti, sāriputta, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn12.31:11.1.eng: “Good, good, Sāriputta!” (The Buddha repeated all of Sāriputta’s explanation, concluding:)

sn12.31:11.2.pli: Bhūtamidanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā bhūtassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn12.31:11.4.pli: Tadāhārasambhavanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā āhārasambhavassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn12.31:11.5.pli: Tadāhāranirodhā yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.

sn12.31:11.6.pli: Tadāhāranirodhā yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā nirodhadhammassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn12.31:12.3.pli: Bhūtamidanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā bhūtassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto hoti.

sn12.31:12.5.pli: Tadāhārasambhavanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā āhārasambhavassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto hoti.

sn12.31:12.6.pli: Tadāhāranirodhā yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.

sn12.31:12.7.pli: Tadāhāranirodhā yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ nirodhadhammanti yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññā disvā nirodhadhammassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto hoti.

sn12.31:12.9.pli: Iti kho, sāriputta, yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ pārāyane ajitapañhe:

sn12.31:14.1.pli: Imassa kho, sāriputta, saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti.
sn12.31:14.1.eng: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what was said in brief.”
